study.title: Antibiotic susceptibility patterns of bacteria isolates from post-operative wound infections among patients attending Mama Lucy Kibaki Hospital, Kenya

design.inclusion_criteria_text: Patients of all age groups with surgical site infection following general, obstetrics and gynecological surgeries.

eligibility.population: Surgical patients with surgical site infections drawn from surgical, maternity, and pediatric wards.
eligibility.intervention: Not specified; study focused on prevalence and susceptibility patterns, not interventions.

populations.description: All patients with surgical site infections attending Mama Lucy Kibaki Hospital between October 2018 and March 2019.

provenance.text_snippet: A total of 58 cases of surgical site infection were observed at the facility between October 2018 and March 2019.

definitions.resistance_definition_text: Antibiotic susceptibility testing performed by Kirby Bauer disc diffusion method; breakpoints provided by CLSI and BSAC.

lab_methods.specimen_collection_method: Pus swabs aseptically obtained from deep viable tissues of the wound by the Levine method.
lab_methods.culture_method: Inoculation on MacConkey agar and blood agar, incubated at 35-37°C for 24h.
lab_methods.QC_measures: Escherichia coli ATCC 25922 and Staphylococcus aureus ATCC 25923 used as control strains.
lab_methods.organism_identification_method: Gram stain, colony characteristics, biochemical tests (catalase, coagulase, urease, indole, methyl red, Voges Proskauer, citrate).
lab_methods.contamination_handling: Immediate surface exudates and contaminants cleansed off with sterile moistened gauze and normal saline before swab collection.
lab_methods.lab_capacity_notes: Samples transported to Kenyatta University laboratory.

codes.summary: High rates of resistance to ampicillin and amoxycillin (>90%) were observed among both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria isolates from SSI wounds.

evidence_quotes.quote: Ampicillin and amoxycillin recorded resistance rates >90% against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.

codes.location_context: Mama Lucy Kibaki Hospital, Nairobi, Kenya

provenance.text_snippet: Ampicillin and amoxycillin recorded resistance rates >90% against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.

codes.summary: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) accounted for 65.4% of Staphylococcus species isolated from SSI wounds.

evidence_quotes.quote: Methicillin-resistant S. aureus accounted for 65.4% (n=17) of the total Staphylococcus species.

codes.location_context: Mama Lucy Kibaki Hospital, Nairobi, Kenya

provenance.text_snippet: Methicillin-resistant S. aureus accounted for 65.4% (n=17) of the total Staphylococcus species.

codes.summary: A total of 58 cases of surgical site infection were observed over a 6-month period, with most isolates recovered from abdominal wounds.

evidence_quotes.quote: A total of 58 cases of surgical site infection were observed at the facility between October 2018 and March 2019.
Most of the bacteria were recovered from the abdomen 60.3% and the lower limbs 29.5%, with the arms and other body sites accounting for 3.8 and 6.4% of the total bacteria (Table 1).

The study included patients of all age groups with surgical site infection following general, obstetrics and gynecological surgeries.
